bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, March 9, 1905

div1.p: Carroll presents a chronology of Walter Reed's involvement with the Yellow Fever Commission. Carroll gives his own autobiography and provides information on the other participants in the study.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, March 9, 1905

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
March 9, 1905.

div1.p:
In response to the request
conveyed in your letter of February 24th I
take pleasure in communicating the following
which is approximately accurate.

In obedience to the War Department order
convening the board Dr Reed and I sailed
from New York June 21st 1900 and reached
Havana June 25th. The board was organized
and work begun immediately. On August
4th Dr Reed returned to the United States, remained
there about two months and then returned
after the death of Dr Lazear to collect data
for the preliminary report. This required
about a week or ten days after which he
again returned to the United States to com-
plete the report and present it at the
meeting of the Am. Public Health Association
as Indianapolis toward the end of October
2.
About November 1st he sailed again for
Havana, to take up the second series of
experiments intended to be confirmatory of
the first. His final departure from Havana
was about February 7th or 8th 1901.

After his return to the United States
his time was taken up with various
matters of routine, among them correspondence
with Major Gorgas who was then engaged
in clearing Havana of yellow fever and under
whom Dr Guiteras was working to confirm
the results of the Commission and establish, if
possible the theory of Dr Finley that immunity
against yellow fever could be conferred through
the bites of recently contaminated mosquitoes
and the subject escape any attack of the
disease now and in the future; and further
that the bite of a single insect would convey
a mild attack while multiple bites would
be followed by a severe attack. The opposite
was shown to be the case.

Dr Reed was Professor of Bacteriology and
clinical Microscopy at the Army Medical School
and Professor of Bacteriology and Pathology at
the Columbian University, Washington, D.C. He
firmly believed that smallpox is conveyed by
a biting insect and we made some attempts
to variolate calves by causing them to be
bitten by bed bugs that had previously been
applied to patients suffering with small pox.

In regard to myself there is nothing
of interest to be related, I have been a
wandering good-for-nothing who fell in
love at 14 and left home at 15, roughed it
in the Canadian backswoods for several
years and finally drifted into the Army.
I have served twenty-four years as a
soldier, four and a half years as a Contract
Surgeon and two and a half in the Medical
Corps as First Lieutenant and Assistant
Surgeon, While still a soldier I studied
4.
medicine at the University of the City of
New York and the University of Maryland,
graduating at the latter school, and took
post graduate courses in Bacteriology and
Pathology at the Johns Hopkins Hospital
in the early nineties, before the establishment
of the medical school.

The fact of which I am especially
proud is that I was the first to succumb
to experimental mosquito inoculation.
Dr Lazear applied a single contaminated
insect to my arm on August 27th 1900 and
I was taken sick August 31st with an attack
free from black vomit but so severe that on
three successive days it was reported I would
not recover. With a wife and five young
children at home my thoughts may be better
imagined than described. This recollection
brings back the look of terror in poor
Lazear's eyes when he realized that black
vomit was impending.

On the day that I was taken sick Lazear
applied the same mosquito to a soldier who
came down with a mild attack of yellow
fever five days later.

A letter addressed to Dr Aristides
Agramonte at the University of Havana or
in care of Dr Charles Finlay will surely
reach him.

At the Surgeon General's Office I learn
that the address of Dr R. P. Cooke is,
Boyce, Virginia.

The addresses of Kissinger and
Moran I am unable to obtain there.

The two soldiers who slept in the in-
fected clothing house with Dr Cooke were
Privates Folk and Jernegan. These three
were followed by Privates Hanberry and
Weatherwalks and these in turn by Privates
Hildebrands and England. Folk, Jernegan
and Hanberry afterward submitted to
experimental inoculation and suffered
(over)
6.
attacks of yellow fever in consequence.

I am truly delighted though not
surprised at the progress Dr Kelly is
making and wish him the fullest
measure of success. It will always afford
me pleasure to give any aid within
my power.
